columns.text: This exercise requires us to identify the effect of stock repurchase, no. of shares outstanding and price per share after the repurchase and show how repurchase is effectively the same as a cash dividend.
**Stock Repurchase**, or also known as buyback, is the re-acquisition by a company on its own shares.

Let's identify the given amounts in the problem. 

| |Amounts | 
|--|--:| 
|Cash |$ 53,700 | 
| Fixed Assets|385,000 | 
| Equity |438,700| 
|Cash Dividend per share |1.30 | 
|Stock Repurchase|18,200|
| No. of Shares Outstanding|14,000 |

First, we need to identify the effect of the stock repurchase. 

The  effect will be the stock repurchase **reduces the company's cash and shareholders' equity by $18,200**.

Next, we will compute the new share outstanding. But before that, let's compute the number of shares bought by dividing the stock repurchase by the stock price. 

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{Share Bought } &= \dfrac{\text{Stock Repurchase}}{\text{Stock Price}}\\[10pt]
&= \dfrac{\text{\$ 18,200}}{\text{\$ 31.34}}\\[10pt]
&=\boxed{\text{580.81 shares}}\\
\end{aligned}$$

Next, we will now compute the new share outstanding by deducting the shares bought from the shares outstanding.

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{New Shares Outsanding} &= \text{Share Outstanding}-{\text{Shares Bought}}\\[5pt]
&= \text{14,000}-{\text{580.81}}\\[5pt]
&=\boxed{\textbf{13,419.19 shares}}\\
\end{aligned}$$

Therefore, the new shares outstanding of the company are **13,419.19 shares**.

Next, we will compute the new stock price after the stock repurchase by dividing the difference between equity value and stock repurchase to the new shares outstanding. 

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{New Stock Price} &= \dfrac{\text{Equity Value}-\text{Stock Repurchase}}{\text{New Shares Outstanding}}\\[10pt]
&= \dfrac{\text{\$ 438,700 - \$ 18,200 }}{\text{13,419.19 }}\\[10pt]
&=\boxed{\textbf{\$ 31.34}}\\
\end{aligned}$$

Therefore, the new stock price  of the company after the stock repurchase is **$31.34**.
A stock repurchase is the same as paying an equal-value cash dividend because the company either holds a share worth $31.34 or a share worth $30.04 and a $1.30 cash dividend.
